intro: Aulotandra trigonocarpa var. trigonocarpa, commonly known as the three-angled fruit tree, is a species native to parts of Southeast Asia. It is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree characterized by its trifoliate leaves and distinctive triangular fruits. The plant belongs to the family Anacardiaceae, which includes other economically important species like mango and cashew. Its botanical features include rough, fissured bark and small, yellowish flowers that appear in clusters. The fruit, which is edible, is typically harvested when it turns red or orange, indicating maturity.
